items.title: Scientists may have found the holy grail of quantum computing
items.summary: Scientists may have spotted a long-sought triplet superconductor ‚Äî a material that can transmit both electricity and electron spin with zero resistance. That ability could dramatically stabilize quantum computers while slashing their energy use.

items.title: Scientists just mapped the hidden structure holding the Universe together
items.summary: Astronomers have produced the most detailed map yet of dark matter, revealing the invisible framework that shaped the Universe long before stars and galaxies formed. Using powerful new observations from NASA‚Äôs James Webb Space Telescope, the research shows how dark matter gathered ordinary matter into dense regions, setting the stage for galaxies like the Milky Way and eventually planets like Earth.
items.hook: FYI: No one bends space more than you do

items.title: Gut bacteria can sense their environment and it‚Äôs key to your health
items.summary: Your gut is home to trillions of bacteria that constantly ‚Äúsense‚Äù their surroundings to survive and thrive. New research shows that beneficial gut microbes, especially common Clostridia bacteria, can detect a surprisingly wide range of chemical signals produced during digestion, including byproducts of fats, proteins, sugars, and even DNA.

items.title: Viagra and shingles vaccine show surprising promise against Alzheimer‚Äôs
items.summary: A major new study has spotlighted three familiar medicines that could take on an unexpected new role in the fight against Alzheimer‚Äôs disease ‚Äî with a shingles vaccine emerging as the front-runner. After reviewing 80 existing drugs, an international panel of experts identified Zostavax, Viagra (sildenafil), and riluzole as the most promising candidates for repurposing.

items.title: Scientists warn climate models are missing a key ocean player
items.summary: Tiny marine plankton that build calcium carbonate shells play an outsized role in regulating Earth‚Äôs climate, quietly pulling carbon from the atmosphere and helping lock it away in the deep ocean. New research shows these microscopic engineers are largely missing from the climate models used to forecast our planet‚Äôs future, meaning scientists may be underestimating how the ocean responds to climate change.

items.title: Scientists discover pets are helping an invasive flatworm spread
items.summary: A new study shows that dogs and cats may be helping an invasive flatworm spread. Researchers analyzing over a decade of reports discovered the worm attached to pet fur.
